column1: Sahuarita  is a town in Pima County
column2: Arizona
column3: United States. Sahuarita is located south of the Tohono O'odham Nation and abuts the north end of Green Valley
column4: 15 miles (24 km) south of Tucson. The population was 25

column1: Sahuarita was founded in 1911 and incorporated in 1994.
The first known human inhabitants of the Sahuarita region were the Hohokam people
column2: which may be the ancestors of the modern day Tohono O'odham nation. The Hohokam were known for their highly innovative and extensive use of irrigation. The Hohokam were a very peaceful people
column3: they had extensive trade routes extending to Mesoamerica
column4: and showed many cultural influences from their southern neighbors.

column1: The Sobaipuri were possibly related to the Hohokam
column2: and occupied the Southern portion of the Santa Cruz
column3: with the Pima to their North and South. While Coronado passed just east of Sahuarita in 1521
column4: it wasn't until Eusebio Kino's 1691 journey along the Santa Cruz River that he met the leaders of the Sobaipuri people.  Kino was a true champion of the indigenous Indians
column5: opposing forced labor in mines by Spanish overseers. Kino would later go on to found the Mission San Xavier del Bac in 1699
column6: just north of Sahuarita. In 1775
column7: Francisco Garcés would follow the same path
column8: laying the groundwork for the founding of Tucson.

column2: after building a series of missions in the region
column3: the Spanish established a fort in the Tucson region to control the Native American settlements nearby. This just north of Sahuarita
column4: which effectively placed the region under Spanish control. Eventually a town came to be and was named Tucson. After the Mexican War of Independence in 1821
column5: the region came under Mexican control until they sold the land to the United States as part of the Gadsden Purchase.

column2: following the Gadsden Purchase
column3: Sahuarita would become a part of the Territory of New Mexico
column4: in the United States of America. In the same year
column5: Andrew B. Gray would travel the region on behalf of the Texas Western Railroad
column6: in order to run a preliminary survey of the region. Meanwhile
column7: the Native American peoples of the region were being pushed onto each other's land through American expansionism. In 1857
column9: who had acted as a buffer between the hostile Mexicans to the south and Apache to the north
column10: finally collapsed under the pressure and vacated the area
column11: generally moving westward to Papago territory. Sahuarita was part of the Confederate Arizona Territory between 1861 and 1862 before being captured by the Union and incorporated into Arizona Territory in 1863. In 1867
column12: Fort Crittenden was created between Sonoita and Patagonia in order to support the establishment of American settlements in the Santa Cruz Valley. In 1874
column13: the San Xavier reservation was created
column14: now called the Tohono O'odham Reservation
column15: and Native Americans were forcibly relocated to the reservation.

column1: An 1870 map of Arizona shows an "Indian Village" just north of Sahuarita. The earliest known reference to the town can be found on a German map from 1875
column2: which labels the town "Sahuarito". The first known US map to list the town came in 1879
column3: by the US Department of Interior
column4: calling the town "Saurita". The Saurita town name would continue to be found on successive maps of 1880 and 1890.

column2: a 1925 map of "Auto Trails" (e.g. roadways) of Arizona and New Mexico lists "Continental" instead of Sahuarita. The roadway at the time was an "improved road"
column3: one step inferior to a "paved road"
column4: laying the route to what today is called the Old Nogales Highway.

column1: In 1879 Sahuarita Ranch was created by James Kilroy Brown. Brown choose the name Sahuarita due to the preponderance of saguaros in the area. The ranch was used as a staging area between Tucson
column2: Arivaca
column3: and Quijotoa. A small community developed in the area named Sahuarito
column4: while the railroad laid tracks through the area (which remain to this day) and established a station and post office. Although originally surveyed by the Texas Western Railroad
column5: the route would soon be run by the Southern Pacific Railroad up until the late 20th century. Brown sold his ranch in 1886 which caused the region to stagnate for three decades.During this time
column6: the hub of Sahuarita commerce was at the intersection of Sahuarita Road and Nogales Highway
column7: in the form of the One Stop Market and Sahuarita Bar and Grill. These 130-year-old buildings which remained intact were demolished for a road expansion in 2013.

column1: The Continental Farm of Sahuarita plays a central role in town history. In 1915
column2: worried about the possibility of a German blockade of rubber imports
column3: Bernard Baruch
column4: Joseph Kennedy and J.P. Morgan founded the farm along the Santa Cruz River with hopes of growing guayule: plants that provide rubber. The project was abandoned after the end of World War I
column6: was sold to Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands. The Queen rented the land to cotton farmers
column7: in what would be the primary crop for the following four decades. In 1948
column8: R. Keith Walden relocated the Farmers Investment Co. (FICO) from California to Arizona
column9: buying the Continental Farm lands from the Queen. In 1965
column10: over fears of a fall in demand for cotton resulting from the advent of synthetic fibers
column11: Walden switched his crop to pecans. Today
column12: the FICO pecan orchard is the largest in the world

column2: Sahuarita was home to the Sahuarita Airstrip which was used to train bomber pilots for service in the war. Camp Continental
column3: a labor camp for German prisoners of war was also located in Sahuarita. The location of the camp was around what is now Continental Ranch
column4: West of the Nogales Highway and the Quail Crossing Boulevard intersection. It was established around November
column6: as one of 21 "branch" POW camps established throughout the state. The population of 250 prisoners primarily worked in agriculture
column7: tending to cotton and vegetable crops. More than one escape attempt was made by the Germans

column1: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is continuing its longstanding efforts of identifying remaining munitions
column2: preventing environmental contamination
column3: and protecting several endangered species in the area
column4: including jaguars
column6: among others. Several different types of expended ammunition rounds can be found throughout the range
column7: most of which found are 10 to 20 mm anti-aircraft rounds. Shrapnel from the dropped ordnance also litters the range
column8: as well as dozens of crushed olive drab ammunition boxes. Shell casings and magazine clips can also be found
column9: along with JATO tanks and large cross targets
column10: constructed of wood with orange reflectors for visibility from the air. The crosses were used as targets for the airmen in training. Many United States Tobacco Company tins have been found
column11: discarded by the several different aviators who occupied the area during its military days. The actual airstrip is now used as a road leading to Sahuarita Park and the Edge Charter School
column12: both of which were built among the remains of the older air force buildings.

column1: Sahuarita contains the Titan Missile Museum
column2: built in 1963 during the height of the Cold War
column3: which is the only Titan Missile site in the world accessible to the public. The actual Titan II missile
column4: the most powerful nuclear missile on standby in the US
column5: remains in the silo for visitors to see. The Sahuarita Airstrip continued to be used by the U.S. Air Force throughout most of the Cold War.

column2: water sustainability is a major concern. According to a 2007 report by Pima County
column4: 000 acre feet (94
column6: 000 m3) of water was pumped from the aquifer in the Upper Santa Cruz Valley in 2006 [in the report referred to as the Green Valley area
column7: which includes Sahuarita]
column8: with 85 percent of that water being used for mining and agriculture. The remaining 15 percent was split between water used for golf courses and residential/commercial water use. The report explains that "The Green Valley area does not have a sustainable water supply given current groundwater pumping rates... the water table in Green Valley has been declining in past years
column9: and is expected to decline even faster as water demands [continue to increase]...". The report concludes that "Water supplies will become critical within the next ten years."The Upper Santa Cruz Valley has several "major water users"
column10: all pumping water out of the same aquifer. None of these are owned by Pima County
column12: nor Green Valley. The major water users are all private companies: ASARCO-Mission Mine
column13: Phelps Dodge Sierrita Mine; Farmers Water Company; Sahuarita Water Company
column16: Community Water Company of Green Valley
column17: and the Green Valley Water District. The proliferation of water companies can be partially explained by the fact that the actual water in the aquifer is not owned by anyone
column18: thus any amount of water can be pumped out
column19: with costs limited only to drilling

column2: which means that natural ecological changes within the lake that do "not fit within the parameters set by man"
column3: are cause for remedial action to return to the goals of the management plan. Air compressors located at various points under the lake continually inject air through diffusers which aids the movement of water in a process called vertical mixing. This system of continual aeration enables the circulation of all water in the lake on a daily basis
column4: and therefore creates an ecological balance and uniform appearance. The lake also contains fish and frogs
column5: the former of which are regularly stocked by the Arizona State Department of Game and Fish
column6: and is an attraction to ducks and various kinds of birds.The lake consumes water to the extent that all the water in the lake must be replenished every year. Regarding water evaporation
column7: lake documents state that according to the USDA Water Conservation Laboratory in Phoenix
column8: the mean annual evaporation rate for Sahuarita is 69 inches (1
column9: 800 mm) per year. This results in a mean water loss of 57.5 acre feet (70
column10: 900 m3) per year. Regarding water loss due to seepage
column11: initial estimates indicated an annual loss of 10 acre feet (12
column13: or 17% of total capacity per year. The J. Harlan Glenn Engineers that provided this estimate indicated that this equates to an "extremely low seepage rate". On average
column14: 65 gpm (gallons of water per minute) must be pumped into the lake to maintain its current level. A nearby well site that draws on the shared Upper Santa Cruz Valley aquifer is used to refill the lake. In 2006

column1: The Town of Sahuarita operates under the council-manager form of government. The Sahuarita town council is responsible for the policy matters of the town
column2: and the management of a town manager to oversee staff and carry out the day-to-day functions of the town.

column1: Sahuarita is administered by the seven member town council
column2: which includes a Mayor and Vice Mayor. The Mayor and Vice Mayor are not elected into those positions
column3: but are instead chosen among elected council members. The town council oversees all issues pertaining to Sahuarita
column4: including residential and commercial development and natural preservation.The Town of Sahuarita is a general law town
column5: and does not have a town charter. As a result
column6: Sahuarita operates fully under Title 9: Cities and Towns
column7: of the Arizona Revised Statutes.
